title: When you sing, is it better to breathe through your mouth or breath through your nose? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a question that has actually gotten significant discussion among vocal pedagogues. There are a few schools of thought on this right now but basically it boils down to the following three: Nose only. When you breathe through your nose your larynx goes down, and we like that!Yes, it’s good when your larynx is down but nose only can allow you to push down the larynx with your tongue. Inhaling through the nose and mouth simultaneously is the best plan.Doesn’t matter where the air comes from, it matters how you use it. If you sing well, you’ll be happy.So obviously this isn’t really resolved, and voice teachers will argue about it possibly forever. If you’re asking my personal belief, I’m basically in camp 3.

Breathing is fairly essential for singing and your technique of breathing is even more so. A lot of factors are dependent on this one single factor and if your breathing technique is not right then my friend you will definitely be facing a lot of troubles. Now, it boils down if breathing technique is so important then what’s the correct way to do it? Here it goes: Major part of breathing while singing is dependent on your breath control which means the control you can keep on your breath to affect a certain thing which in this case is the way you sing.Ideally, you can breathe from your nose as well as your mouth (whatever works for you) but you gotta make sure that you aren’t stacking up air and aren’t singing through your nose.If you do feel that you sing through your nose then here’s a quick resolution for you:
Nasal singing is very hard to learn and hard to understand.   I recommend you stick to singing (exhaling) via mouth.  How you inhale is irrelevant because singing happens only when you exhale
According to all classical training by the Italian Mastero, breathing through the nose it totally forbidden unless you are singing in Vietnamese, SE Asian languages, or American country singing.
